OverallSummary: From June 2018 to February 2020, Cova Capital Partners recommended and sold private placement offerings from Issuer 1 to nine investors totaling over $2 million, without conducting proper due diligence. The firm failed to verify that Issuer 1 actually possessed the pre-IPO shares of Company A it was purporting to sell, and did not determine the markups being applied. The SEC later filed fraud charges against Issuer 1 for charging undisclosed, excessive markups and not having enough pre-IPO shares to satisfy investor sales.

From October 2019 to 2021, Cova Capital Partners recommended and sold private placement offerings from Issuer 2 to 24 investors totaling over $1.7 million, without conducting proper due diligence. The firm failed to reasonably investigate Issuer 2's management and did not identify that the CEO was previously the subject of federal and state regulatory actions related to illegal robocalls to senior consumers.

From September 2021 to December 2021, Cova Capital Partners recommended and sold private placement offerings from Issuer 3 to 49 investors totaling over $9 million, without conducting proper due diligence. The firm failed to verify that Issuer 3 actually possessed the pre-IPO shares of Company B it was purporting to sell, and failed to investigate SEC charges filed against two individuals associated with another pre-IPO fund from which Issuer 3 claimed to source Company B shares.
